Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 06:41AM windy2011 wrote: My advice is to go with the mastectomy -- if you have had 2 breast cancers in one breast, my thinking is that you are bound to have another.  There is no way for the doctors to tell if you have tiny cells in your breast just waiting to grow.  Plus surgery sucks so much, why not get it over with?  They can reconstruct.  They haven't been able to control my cancer enough to consider a mastectomy for me, but I would jump at the chance (although I appreciate that I haven't had to lose a breast yet).  I already have growth again in the breast that I had a lumpectomy in.  Plus consider that you don't want to regret not getting the mastectomy if the cancer starts to flourish -- I guess in the end, go with whatever you will have the least regrets about.  I say 2 strikes and off with the breast!
Posts.Title: New primary with different receptors...mastectomy vs. lumpectomy lissyross lissyross

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 02:35PM windy2011 wrote: You all are so sweet.  I've been here a little over a month now and I feel like I'm starting to get to know you all.  Thanks so much.  I almost feel like I have no right to be too down when I feel great physically...almost.  I know this diagnosis is still "a ton of bricks to carry around" as chainsawz says, but on the other hand I want to feel "normal" for as long as possible.  I guess what I am saying is I think my problems pale in comparison to many others here, so thanks again to all of you for taking the time to help me through this.
Posts.Title: PMS/ Feeling Down HELP! windy2011 sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 06:59AM windy2011 wrote: Thanks Elizabeth, It helps to know that even though this disease may progress (I won't accept that it will, you know, the power of positive thinking), that I still might feel ok for a long time.  I have been healthy as a horse my whole life.  I don't handle sickness or pain well at all.  I am a lousy patient too...I find it easier to be difficult than sweet when I am a patient.  Oh well, it's the medical team's job, right?  hahaha You are right, all things are relative.  One thing I'm struggling with now is a lack of compassion for anyone who is not stage 4.  My compassion seems to have gone away.   I recently met a young man who admitted to me that he recently tried to kill himself.  It was like divine intervention that our paths crossed.  He doesn't know that I'm fighting for my life while he's caught up in being 26 and feeling sorry for himself/ obviously depressed.  Well I hope some good comes of my situation for him...maybe through me he'll see how valuable his life is.   I do have compassion for him so maybe it hasn't gone away.  I just don't care about other people's problems (who aren't in our shoes) anymore (for the most part).  Maybe I only have compassion when it is life or death. Now I'm blathering on... Windy
Posts.Title: PMS/ Feeling Down HELP! windy2011 sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 02:20PM windy2011 wrote: Update...Thanks to all of you who took the time to write me.  I FINALLY got my period and the clouds have lifted and the angels are singing.  I feel SO much better emotionally.  This means the tamoxifen has not caused depression (yet?).  I've been on it for less than a month though.  Still, good news and thanks to all who were concerned about my little problem.  You are great. Windy
Posts.Title: PMS/ Feeling Down HELP! windy2011 sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 06:45PM windy2011 wrote: Good advice ladies.  I forgot that depression was a side effect.  Yes, I have been depressed before, but it bugs me to take medicine.  I'll force myself to exercise every morning and then reevaluate after I finish my period.  Waiting for that and hoping it will release the dark cloud.  Windy
Posts.Title: PMS/ Feeling Down HELP! windy2011 sincitydealer

Posts.Content: windy2011 wrote: I am recently diagnosed, have no symptoms, but emotionally am on a rollercoaster that is very low right now.  I also have extreme PMS, maybe it is worse on tamoxifen?  Or maybe it is worse because it is the first time I have had PMS knowing I'm stage 4.  I just want my life to be normal again so bad.  Then there's Olga, so young, so sad.  Windy Dx 12/27/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 3/6 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

It seems that I always post here when I am at my lowest.  I have friends and family that I can talk to here, but really talking isn't the answer.  I need some way to turn this horrific situation positive.  I don't know that I will find a way...

Posts.Content: windy2011 wrote: I just found out yesterday that I have a 95% chance of being in stage 4.  I was ready to go to surgery on Monday for a mastectomy and reconstruction, but my Pet scan showed a spot on my liver and bones.  Have absorbed the news some, but am absolutely terrified of the unknown.  I know I need to deal with the fear and learn to live with the uncertainty that goes with this disease.  But I am just scared, scared, scared, scared and scared!!!  I know this feeling must fade with time, so please tell me how it has faded for you? Dx 12/27/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 3/6 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Feeling terrified, afraid, scared windy2011 Heidihill

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 08:09PM windy2011 wrote: Thanks everyone!  I really appreciate the support.  I am determined to beat this too, and to not let this become the focus of my life.  This is why this forum is so great, I can unload my medical horror stories on all of you rather than whoever I come across in life.  I guess I'm walking a line between acceptance and "maybe they are wrong" right now.  I'm looking forward to a second opinion.  My ex husband is finding the best oncologist out there (he said maybe Mayo in Chicago?) and my ex boyfriend (I knew we stayed friends for a reason haha) used to work for NIH so he is looking into clinical trials for me.  I know from reading other's stories that I don't have it so bad right now, so I will try to keep the faith, feed off the support I am getting here, and expect the best.  Of course that hasn't really worked up until this point, but I'm not going to quit until I've run out of options.  Being positive does work.  I'm still waiting for it to work for me, but I have to believe that it will help me somehow. Thanks again everyone
Posts.Title: Feeling terrified, afraid, scared windy2011 Heidihill

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2012 08:06PM windy2011 wrote: Anyone with stage 4 breast cancer doesn't need a reason to be emotional.  You probably are afraid that if you get rid of the wig the cancer will come back.  Or you are just afraid because you have cancer.  I'm happy to see you are in remission.  I still haven't done chemo, but I am in the process of getting a wig.  So I'll be ready.  You probably don't want to get too used to your real hair because you might have to use it again.  Just say good-bye to your wig for now, but don't freak out if you will need it again.  You will be fine.   So that's my free analysis -- really just some guesses?
Posts.Title: Why am I so emotional??? Iwillwinthisbattle DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 01:04PM windy2011 wrote: Sorry you must be so worried right now.  Stage 4 is when the cancer has spread beyond the primary site.  The cancer blockage was where?  The tumor UNDER her lymph nodes means it is where?  I would look at that.  It all depends on where the cancer showed up again.  I think as long as it is not in the breast than that would put it in stage 4.  I am new to all this but could see you are going to checking back so good luck.  You can request the Dr. notes from the oncologist with your mom's permission, that might help.  He sounds like a lousy communicator.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Stage 4 or not???? curepink MJLToday

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 10:47PM windy2011 wrote: I don't see any reason or advantage to giving up hope.  Hope springs eternal.  It is a scientific fact that patients do better with a positive attitude.  Kick that man to the curb and surround yourself with people who will love you properly.  No one ever really knows when their time is up.

Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 05:17PM windy2011 wrote: Jenn, Sorry to read your post.  Try not to freak out, remember to live each day to the fullest, and also remember the doctors never seem to know as much as they act like they know.  This could be good or bad I guess.  My point is, you need to believe you will improve.  I'm really just trying to say keep your head up and stay strong.  I keep on reading about how much so many women are helped by various medications/chemos.  Lots of them take time to work.  I'll be thinking and praying for you. Windy
Posts.Title: I WANT MORE TIME! jenn3 AnewBeginning

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 10:36PM windy2011 wrote: Biopsy biopsy biopsy!  I had a clear mammogram in September, a clear ultrasound in November, no one could even feel a lump.  I then had a change in the appearance of my breast in December, then a repeat mammo and sonogram, and low and behold, they found something to biopsy.  It turned out to be breast cancer, and I found out in February that it had spread to my liver and bones.  NOTHING but a biopsy will do.  Do whatever you can to make her get one.  My breast cancer would have shown up on an MRI if anyone had ever ordered one for me.  My daughter will be getting MRIs for sure.
Posts.Title: My daughter, 31, breastfeeding2 months postpartum has lump kayfh windy2011

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 09:34AM windy2011 wrote: Hi Cathy, I'm so sorry that you are dealing with this news.  I found about my mets about one month ago and I can at least tell you that emotionally it will get better.  You will learn how to stuff it aside and enjoy the good moments in life.  I try not to focus on prognosis too much.  I tell myself that my body won't let me down, and I'm going to be someone who lives with this disease for years and years and years.  Try to think positively and know there are lots of great women here who are able to help you.  My heart goes out to you and all of us struggling with this horrific disease.   Windy
Posts.Title: Help Cathy2 cookie97

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 08:23PM windy2011 wrote: Throw a hissy fit!!!  I am new to all of this but in general I am a terrible patient.  I am so angry that I have this AND angry that no one found it for years and years although I always said I had breast pain during my period and ovulation.  THIS IS YOUR LIFE.  The squeaky wheel gets the grease...you need that attention/confidence from your onc that they are fighting for you!  Being positive = better outcome according to science.  I don't think you can be as positive as you can be without feeling like you are getting the best care humanly possible.  Good luck!  I'll be sending my fighting energy your way! Windy

Posts.Title: Really tempted to use the "C" card here... KSkier jenn3

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 10:07PM windy2011 wrote: I have found a lot of people pull away from me.  I think they are afraid of getting more attached, or just of dealing with cancer.  Or they are afraid of 'catching' it.  I know that is ridiculous, but the only way that I understand is that I have been pulling away from people too.  Not all, just some.  It is one of the horrific things about cancer.  Stay strong and don't take anything personally.  It is her, not you, and maybe she'll come around.  I found a number of people in my family who didn't want to face what is happening to me.  Like if they ignore it, it will go away.  I really hope things turn around for you and her.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 11:55AM windy2011 wrote: Thanks.  I am amazed at how many women here are able to stay positive.  I guess this is the big challenge.  I hope all goes well for all of you.  I am going to hang onto the hope that my cancer is moving slow.  And of course I am going to hope that they are wrong!  Oh well.  I guess the other challenge is to move on with the rest of our lives and enjoy each moment as it comes.  My thoughts and prayers are with all of us...such a terrible disease.
Posts.Title: Stage IV with Liver mets (HER2+, ER+/PR +). Journey so far Fatima gonegirl

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2012 06:19PM windy2011 wrote: Sorry you are here, but I noticed that you didn't get a second opinion.  My advice to you is to line up where and who you want the second opinion from now, when you are doing well.  That way if things get worse, you will be ready to act because you will be prepared.  Everyone here should have 2nd opinions, this is a life-threatening diagnosis.
Posts.Title: New to BCO today ! Stalker since January! Redroan Redroan

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 10:39PM windy2011 wrote: Lynwaz, although I glanced at your story before, I just reread it.  So sorry to see this has happened to you.  It is such a horrible disease.  Someone sent me this link crazysexylife.com/about/kris-c... if you haven't seen it, take a look.  I thought it was so encouraging to see someone living with cancer in such a constructive way.  I have given up sugar for now and am trying to only eat the top cancer-fighting foods.  I say I have given up sugar for now but probably forever?  Worth it but a painful thing to say!  Take care Windy
